snippet.textDisplay: You know, on June 20th, I went over to see an orchestral tribute to Nobuo Uematsu's work that was played beautifully. After the intermission, a choir were summoned to the stage and sung this track with such intensity. It truly reminded me how legendary the soundtrack for this game was.

snippet.textDisplay:
Chrono trigger and Cross are without a doubt, the only OSTs that can compete with Uematsu's work in FF.

I'd rank them:

FFVII > FFVI > FFIX > Chrono Cross> FFVIII > Chrono Trigger > FFX > FFIV > FFI > FFV

In terms of all time best ever. FFXIII-LR music being trash, of course.
snippet.textOriginal:
Chrono trigger and Cross are without a doubt, the only OSTs that can compete with Uematsu's work in FF.

I'd rank them:

FFVII > FFVI > FFIX > Chrono Cross> FFVIII > Chrono Trigger > FFX > FFIV > FFI > FFV

In terms of all time best ever. FFXIII-LR music being trash, of course.

snippet.textDisplay:
@NanoEmpyrean 

Mitsuda's great and he composed most of Chrono Trigger's music but just thought I'd point out that "Underground Sewer" and this one("Silent Light") among a couple others such as "Tyran Castle" and "Sealed Door" were composed by Uematsu.  He helped Mitsuda with CT's OST during a period while Mitsuda was being hospitalized.
snippet.textOriginal:
@NanoEmpyrean 

Mitsuda's great and he composed most of Chrono Trigger's music but just thought I'd point out that "Underground Sewer" and this one("Silent Light") among a couple others such as "Tyran Castle" and "Sealed Door" were composed by Uematsu.  He helped Mitsuda with CT's OST during a period while Mitsuda was being hospitalized.

snippet.textDisplay: @masterplusmargarita It comes from people's personal experience; my friends and I played (almost) all JPRG for the SNES(FF series, Secret of mana, super mario rgp, breath of fire, etc), then one of use found out this hidden gem and it was like it just had everything we could even think of: Great music, the graphics were good for SNES, fun combat system with combinations of spells, multiple endings, artwork from our hero Akira Toriyama (lol) and that with other reasons was huge at the time.  :)
snippet.textOriginal: @masterplusmargarita It comes from people's personal experience; my friends and I played (almost) all JPRG for the SNES(FF series, Secret of mana, super mario rgp, breath of fire, etc), then one of use found out this hidden gem and it was like it just had everything we could even think of: Great music, the graphics were good for SNES, fun combat system with combinations of spells, multiple endings, artwork from our hero Akira Toriyama (lol) and that with other reasons was huge at the time.  :)

snippet.textDisplay: I didn't ever really "get" chrono trigger. Sure, it's a good game, not bad at all, but I don't see why people love it. Whilst it definitely isn't a bad game by any stretch of the word, I don't think it deserves the level of hype it gets. It's definitely not at the level of other classics such as FF IV, V and VI, as well as Secret of Mana.
snippet.textOriginal: I didn't ever really "get" chrono trigger. Sure, it's a good game, not bad at all, but I don't see why people love it. Whilst it definitely isn't a bad game by any stretch of the word, I don't think it deserves the level of hype it gets. It's definitely not at the level of other classics such as FF IV, V and VI, as well as Secret of Mana.
